questions.text: Which of the following is a nucleus of basal ganglia?
questions.solution:
The basal ganglia has five nuclei on each side of the brain.

  • Caudate nucleus
  • Putamen
  • Globus pallidus: Divided into globus pallidus external (GPe) and globus pallidus internal (GPi)
  • Substantia nigra: Divided into pars compacta and pars reticulata
  • Subthalamic nucleus

The cau­date nucleus and putamen together form the striatum.

The putamen and globus pallidus collectively form the lentiform nucleus.

questions.text: Which part of the basal ganglia receives the afferent input?
questions.solution:
The striatum receives the afferent input. 

Note:

There are two main inputs to the basal ganglia: From the cerebral cortex (corticostriate pathway) and from the thalamus (thalamostriate pathway). They are both excitatory (glutamate) and they both terminate in the striatum.

The two major outputs of the basal ganglia are from GPi and substantia nigra. Both are inhibitory (GABAergic) and both project to the thalamus.

From the thalamus, there is an excitatory (glutamatergic) projection to the prefrontal and premotor cortex. This completes the cortical-basal ganglia-thalamic-cortical loop.

questions.text: A patient is found to have a hemorrhage in the basal ganglia region. Which of the following is least likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient will have dysfunction of the basal ganglia. Maintenance of equilibrium is a function of the cerebellum and vestibular apparatus, hence will not be affected in this patient.

Functions of basal ganglia:

  • Planning of movements
  • Regulation of muscle tone
  • Control of reflex muscular activity & posture
  • Programming of movement - speed, direction, and intensity
  • Role in the cognitive process (especially caudate nucleus)

questions.text: Glutamate is synthesized mainly in which part of basal ganglia?
questions.solution:
Glutamate is synthesized mainly in the subthalamic nuclei of basal ganglia. 

Connections within the basal ganglia and the respective neurotransmitters:

Connections between Neurotransmitter
Substantia nigra pars compacta to striatum (Nigrostraiatal projection) Dopamine
Striatum to substantia nigra pars reticulata GABA
Striatum to GPe and GPi GABA
GPe to subthalamic nuclei GABA
Subthalamic nuclei to GPe and GPi Glutamate

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with abnormal movements of the limbs. A lesion of the globus pallidus is suspected. Which of the following did she most likely present with?
questions.solution:
This woman with a lesion at the globus pallidus most likely presented with athetosis: Slow, writhing movements of a hand/arm/the face. 

Condition Site of lesion Description 
Chorea Striatum

Flicking movements in the hands, face, and other parts of the body
Athetosis Globus pallidus

Spontaneous, continuous writhing movements of a hand, an arm, the neck, or the face
Hemiballusmus Subthalamic nucleus

Sudden flailing movements of an entire limb
Parkinsonism Substantia nigra

Severe rigidity, akinesia, and tremors

questions.text: Cells present in cerebellar cortex are all except
questions.solution:
Bipolar cells are not present in cerebellum.

Cerebellum has 3 layers, 4 deep nuclei and 5 types of neurons.

The cerebellar cortex has three layers:

  • External molecular layer
  • Purkinje cell layer 
  • Internal granular layer

There are four deep nuclei: D,E,F,G

  • Dentate
  • Emboliform
  • Fastigial nuclei
  • Glo­bose

Interpositus nucleus- Globose and the emboliform nuclei together.

There are five types of neurons in the cortex:

  • Purkinje
  • Granule
  • Basket
  • Stellate
  • Golgi cells

questions.text: All are cerebellar nuclei except______.
questions.solution:
Interpositus nucleus= globose+emboliform nuclei 

Note: Red nucleus is situated in the midbrain. It crosses the midline and projects to interneurons in the dorsolateral part of the spinal ventral horn to also influence motor neurons that control distal limb muscles. This rubrospinal tract excites flexor motor neurons and inhibits extensor motor neurons. This pathway is not prominent in humans, but it may play a role in the posture typical of decorticate rigidity.

questions.text: Efferent from cerebellar cortex is through which cell:
questions.solution:
Purkinje cells are the only output neurons (efferent neurons) from the cerebellar cortex.

The Purkinje cells are the largest neurons in the cerebellum. Their axons, which are the only output from the cerebellar cortex, project to the deep cerebellar nuclei, especially the dentate nucleus, where they form inhibitory synapses.

questions.text: Flocculonodular lobe has direct connections with __________
questions.solution:
The flocculonodular lobe has connections with the vestibular apparatus.

The flocculonodular lobe forms the vestibulocerebellum, which projects to the vestibular nuclei and is concerned with equilibrium and eye movements.

questions.text: Which of the following are climbing fibers?
questions.solution:
Climbing fibers are olivocerebellar fibers. They originate from the inferior olivary nucleus. 

Climbing fibers and mossy fibers are the two main excitatory inputs to the cerebellum.

Climbing fibres Mossy fibres
They come from one single source via the inferior olivary nuclei. They come from many sources and the fibers synapse with granule cells to form glomeruli.

End on single Purkinje cells.

Convey proprioceptive inputs from all over the body.

 Axons of granule cells bifurcate and form parallel fibers which excite multiple Purkinje cells.

Note: Mossy fibres provide direct input via the pontine nuclei.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct?

choices.text: Spino cerebellum constitutes vermis and lateral portion of cerebellar hemisphere
Vestibulo cerebellum constitutes nodulus and flocculus
Vestibulo cerebellum constitutes lateral portion of cerebellar hemispheres

questions.solution:
Vestibulocerebellum (archicerebellum) constitutes nodulus and flocculus and is hence called floculonodular lobe.

Spinocerebellum (paleocerebellum) constitutes vermis and adjacent medial portions of cerebellar hemispheres.

Cerebrocerebellum (neocerebellum) constitutes the lateral portions of hemispheres.

questions.text: Which of the following is a function of the neocerebellum?

choices.text: Planning and programming of voluntary movements

questions.solution:
The function of the neocerebellum is planning and programming of voluntary movements.

The cerebellum can be divided into: 

The Vestibulocerebellum/Archicerebellum: Consists princi­pally of the flocculonodular lobe and adjacent portions of the vermis. It participates in balance, vestibular reflexes, and eye movements.

The Spinocerebellum/Paleocerebellum: Consists of most of the vermis plus the adjacent intermediate zones on both sides of the vermis. It coordi­nates movements of the limbs. Vermis: Proximal muscles, Intermediate zones: Distal muscles

The Cerebrocerebellum/neocerebellum: Consists of the large lateral zones of the cerebellar hemispheres. It receives all its input from the cerebral cortex (motor, premotor and somatosensory). It transmits its output back to the brain, functioning in a feedback manner to plan sequential voluntary body and limb movements.

questions.text: A patient with a cerebellar lesion will show all of the following features except:
questions.solution:
A patient with a suspected cerebellar lesion will not have resting tremors. Resting tremors are characteristic features of basal ganglia lesions.  (Parkinson's disease).

Intentional tremors are seen in cerebellar diseases.

Features of cerebellar disease

  • Ataxia – Incoordinated, intermittent jerky movements with drunken gait.
  • Hypotonia or atonia – Reduced or absence of muscle tone.
  • Dysmetria – Inability to judge the force and range of movement resulting in past pointing.
  • Dysdiadokokinesia – Failure to perform rapid alternating movements.
  • Decomposition of movement – Lack of smooth flow of movement.
  • Speech defect – Staccato speech or slurring speech.
  • Pendular knee jerk (a feature of hypotonia).
  • Intention tremors.
  • Nystagmus (jerky movements of the eye).
  • Rebound phenomenon.

questions.text: The vestibulo-ocular reflex is being performed in a patient with vertigo. Which of the following is associated with this reflex?
questions.solution:
The vestibulo-ocular reflex is controlled by the vestibulo-cerebellum, which constitutes the flocculonodular lobe.

questions.text: Purkinje fibers are inhibitory for _________.
questions.solution:
The input from the Purkinje cells to the deep nuclei is inhibitory.

However, the deep nuclei output is always excitatory.

Related Pearl: Cerebellar Circuitry

Cerebellar circuitry includes:

Afferents- Climbing and mossy fibers

  • Climbing fibers -
    • Origin - contralateral inferior olivary nucleus in the medulla oblongata
    • Terminates on - Purkinje cell
  • Mossy fibers -
    • Origin - multiple sources in the spinal cord and brainstem
    • Terminates on - Granule cell

Intrinsic components

  • Granule cell backward inhibition - done by Golgi cells- prevent transmission from mossy fibers to the granule cells
  • Purkinje cells forward inhibition- done by stellate and basket cells

Efferents -

  • The output from the cerebellar cortex - from Purkinje cells inhibitory output to the deep cerebellar nuclei
  • The output from the cerebellum - from deep cerebellar nuclei
    • Globose, emboliform, and dentate - via superior cerebellar peduncle
    • Fastigial - via inferior cerebellar peduncle

questions.text: Which of the following fibres reach the Purkinje cell directly?
questions.solution:
The fibres of inferior olivary nucleus (climbing fibres) reach the purkinje cell directly.

Note: 

The input from the Purkinje cells to the deep nuclei is inhibitory.

However, the deep nuclei output is always excitatory.

questions.text: Which of the following is true?

choices.text: Molecular layer contain stellate and basket cells
Molecular is the innermost layer of cortex
Axons of purkinje cell secrete Glutamate on deep cerebellar nuclei

questions.solution:
The cerebellar cortex has three layers:

External molecular layer: Contains Basket and Stellate Cells.  

Purkinje cell layer: Only one cell thick, containing the purkinje cells.

Internal granular layer: Contains Granule and Golgi Cells

questions.text: Which of the following ascending pathways enters the cerebellum through the peduncle highlighted in green in the image?
questions.solution:
The peduncle highlighted in the image is the superior cerebellar peduncle. The anterior spinocerebellar tract enters the cerebellum through it and terminates in both sides of the cerebellum. 

Dorsal spinocerebellar tract enters the cerebellum through the inferior cerebellar peduncle and terminates on the same side as its origin.

questions.text: Concerning the circuitry between mossy fibers, climbing fibers and cells of the cerebellar cortex, which of the following pairs provide excitatory input?

choices.text: Granule cell parallel fibers and mossy fibers

questions.solution:
The excitatory fibers in the cerebellum are climbing fibers, mossy fibers, and granule cell parallel fibers. 

The fundamental circuits of the cerebellar cortex :

  • Climbing fibers exert a strong excitatory effect on single Purkinje cells. Mossy fibers exert an excitatory effect on granule cells.
  • Each granule cell sends an axon to the molecular layer, where the axon bifurcates to form a T. The branches of the T are straight and run long distances; thus, they are called parallel fibers. The parallel fibers form excitatory synapses on the dendrites of many Purkinje cells.

 

  • The other neurons (basket cells, stellate cells, and golgi cells) are inhibitory interneurons. Basket cells and stellate cells receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and each inhibits many Purkinje cells. Golgi cells receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and mossy fibers. Their axons project to the dendrites of the granule cells where they form an inhibitory synapse.

 

  • The output of the Purkinje cells is ultimately inhibitory to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

Related Pearl: Cerebellar Circuitry

Cerebellar circuitry includes:

Afferents- Climbing and mossy fibers

  • Climbing fibers -
    • Origin - contralateral inferior olivary nucleus in the medulla oblongata
    • Terminates on - Purkinje cell
  • Mossy fibers -
    • Origin - multiple sources in the spinal cord and brainstem
    • Terminates on - Granule cell

Intrinsic components

  • Granule cell backward inhibition - done by Golgi cells- prevent transmission from mossy fibers to the granule cells
  • Purkinje cells forward inhibition- done by stellate and basket cells

Efferents -

  • The output from the cerebellar cortex - from Purkinje cells inhibitory output to the deep cerebellar nuclei
  • The output from the cerebellum - from deep cerebellar nuclei
    • Globose, emboliform, and dentate - via superior cerebellar peduncle

questions.text: Inhibition of Purkinje cells by stellate cells is an example of

choices.text: Stellate cells doesn’t inhibit purkinje cells

questions.solution:
Inhibition of Purkinje cells by stellate cells is an example of feedforward inhibition.

Mossy fibers exert a weak excitatory effect on many Purkinje cells via the granule cells. The granule cells also excite the basket and stellate cells via their parallel fibers. The basket and stellate cells, in turn, inhibit the Purkinje cells (Feed forward inhibition).

Renshaw cells exhibit feedback inhibition.
